Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[OpenTK-1.0] Disable per-TFN IntermediateOutputPath" (#1692) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Commit 13d216fd [broke the build][0], within the `make opentk-jcw`
build target:

[0]: https://jenkins.mono-project.com/view/Xamarin.Android/job/xamarin-android/1003/

	$ msbuild /p:Configuration=Debug /p:AndroidApiLevel=15 /p:AndroidPlatformId=15 /p:AndroidFrameworkVersion=v4.0.3 /t:GenerateJavaCallableWrappers /v:diag src/OpenTK-1.0/OpenTK.csproj
	...
	Target "GenerateJavaCallableWrappers: (TargetId:2)" in file "…/xamarin-android/build-tools/scripts/JavaCallableWrappers.targets" from project "…/xamarin-android/src/OpenTK-1.0/OpenTK.csproj" (entry point):
	Building target "GenerateJavaCallableWrappers" completely.
	Input file "…/xamarin-android/src/OpenTK-1.0/obj/Debug/MonoAndroid403/OpenTK-1.0.dll" does not exist.
	...
	mono --debug=casts "…/xamarin-android/bin/Debug/lib/xamarin.android/xbuild/Xamarin/Android/jcw-gen.exe" -v10 -o "…/xamarin-android/src/OpenTK-1.0/obj/Debug/MonoAndroid403/jcw/src" -L "…/xamarin-android/bin/Debug/lib/xamarin.android/xbuild-frameworks/MonoAndroid/v4.0.3/" -L "…/xamarin-android/bin/Debug/lib/xamarin.android/xbuild-frameworks/MonoAndroid/v4.0.3/../v1.0" -L "…/xamarin-android/bin/Debug/lib/xamarin.android/xbuild-frameworks/MonoAndroid/v4.0.3/../v1.0/Facades" "…/xamarin-android/src/OpenTK-1.0/obj/Debug/MonoAndroid403/OpenTK-1.0.dll" (TaskId:3)
	jcw-gen: System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load assembly 'OpenTK-1.0, Version=0.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken='. Perhaps it doesn't exist in the Mono for Android profile? (TaskId:3)
	File name: 'OpenTK-1.0.dll' (TaskId:3)
	  at Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil.DirectoryAssemblyResolver.Resolve (Mono.Cecil.AssemblyNameReference reference, Mono.Cecil.ReaderParameters parameters) [0x000c3] in …/xamarin-android/external/Java.Interop/src/Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil/Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil/DirectoryAssemblyResolver.cs:241  (TaskId:3)
	  at Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil.DirectoryAssemblyResolver.Resolve (Mono.Cecil.AssemblyNameReference reference) [0x00001] in …/xamarin-android/external/Java.Interop/src/Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil/Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil/DirectoryAssemblyResolver.cs:191  (TaskId:3)
	  at Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil.AssemblyResolverCoda.GetAssembly (Mono.Cecil.IAssemblyResolver resolver, System.String fileName) [0x00001] in …/xamarin-android/external/Java.Interop/src/Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil/Java.Interop.Tools.Cecil/DirectoryAssemblyResolver.cs:48  (TaskId:3)
	  at Java.Interop.Tools.JavaCallableWrappers.JavaTypeScanner.GetJavaTypes (System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1[T] assemblies, Mono.Cecil.IAssemblyResolver resolver) [0x0001c] in …/xamarin-android/external/Java.Interop/src/Java.Interop.Tools.JavaCallableWrappers/Java.Interop.Tools.JavaCallableWrappers/JavaTypeScanner.cs:31  (TaskId:3)
	  at Java.Interop.Tools.App.Main (System.String[] args) [0x001f2] in …/xamarin-android/external/Java.Interop/tools/jcw-gen/App.cs:66  (TaskId:3)
	...
	make: *** [opentk-jcw] Error 1

The reason for the failure is because of an interaction between commit
46de66f and 13d216fd: starting with 46de66f,
`make framework-assemblies` only builds *one* version of
`OpenTK-1.0.dll`, the version for the first `$(API_LEVELS)` value.
Once that single `OpenTK-1.0.dll` is built -- with an intermediate
"copy" in `src/OpenTK-1.0/obj/Debug/OpenTK-1.0.dll` -- the same
intermediate assembly is reused by `make opentk-jcw` to generate the
Java Callable Wrappers for `OpenTK-1.0.dll` and inserted into
`mono.android.jar.`

Commit 46de66f screws up this process, because it creates an
environment in which there are *many* intermediate `OpenTK-1.0.dll`
assemblies -- one per `$(TargetFrameworkVersion)` value -- e.g.
`src/OpenTK-1.0/obj/Debug/MonoAndroid23/OpenTK-1.0.dll`.
Unfortunately, the `GenerateJavaCallableWrappers` target doesn't
rebuild `OpenTK-1.0.dll` -- intentionally! for consistency! -- which
is why we get the `Input file "...OpenTK-1.0.dll" does not exist`
message within the output.

The fix? Selectively "revert" 46de66f by having `OpenTK.csproj` set
`$(AppendTargetFrameworkToIntermediateOutputPath)`=False.  This
returns the `OpenTK.csproj` build to the previous state of affairs of
having a single intermediate `OpenTK-1.0.dll` assembly, allowing the
`make opentk-jcw` target to execute without error.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] fix timestamps in various intermediate folders" (#1693) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
When taking an audit of our build times, I was testing the following
scenario:
- `msbuild Droid.csproj /t:Install /bl:first.binlog`
- `msbuild Droid.csproj /t:Install /bl:second.binlog`

In theory, the "second" build should be very fast and basically not do
anything. Unfortunately that was not the case.

In my example, I saw build logs such as:

    Target _LinkAssembliesNoShrink
        Building target "_LinkAssembliesNoShrink" partially, because some output files are out of date with respect to their input files.
        [ResolvedUserAssemblies: Input=C:\Users\myuser\.nuget\packages\xamarin.forms\3.0.0.482510\lib\MonoAndroid10\FormsViewGroup.dll, Output=obj\Debug\android\assets\FormsViewGroup.dll] Input file is newer than output file.
        [ResolvedUserAssemblies: Input=C:\Users\myuser\.nuget\packages\xamarin.forms\3.0.0.482510\lib\MonoAndroid10\Xamarin.Forms.Core.dll, Output=obj\Debug\android\assets\Xamarin.Forms.Core.dll] Input file is newer than output file.
        [ResolvedUserAssemblies: Input=C:\Users\myuser\.nuget\packages\xamarin.forms\3.0.0.482510\lib\MonoAndroid10\Xamarin.Forms.Platform.Android.dll, Output=obj\Debug\android\assets\Xamarin.Forms.Platform.Android.dll] Input file is newer than output file.
        [ResolvedUserAssemblies: Input=C:\Users\myuser\.nuget\packages\xamarin.forms\3.0.0.482510\lib\MonoAndroid10\Xamarin.Forms.Platform.dll, Output=obj\Debug\android\assets\Xamarin.Forms.Platform.dll] Input file is newer than output file.
        [ResolvedUserAssemblies: Input=C:\Users\myuser\.nuget\packages\xamarin.forms\3.0.0.482510\lib\MonoAndroid10\Xamarin.Forms.Xaml.dll, Output=obj\Debug\android\assets\Xamarin.Forms.Xaml.dll] Input file is newer than output file.
        LinkAssemblies

Looking at the `LinkAssemblies` MSBuild task, I didn't see anything
that would be setting the timestamps on copied files.

For timestamps to be correct, we should either:
- Use `MonoAndroidHelper.SetLastAccessAndWriteTimeUtc` in C#
- Use the `<Touch />` MSBuild task after using the `<Copy />` MSBuild
  task

This lead me to write a `CheckTimestamps` unit test that does the
following:
- Store `DateTime.UtcNow` in a variable
- Build an app
- Make sure nothing in `bin` or `obj` are older than the start time

This uncovered even more out of date files such as:
- `mono.android.jar`
- Assemblies in `obj/Debug/linksrc` or `$(MonoAndroidLinkerInputDir)`

Fixes made in various places:
- `<LinkAssemblies />` task needed to use
  `MonoAndroidHelper.SetLastAccessAndWriteTimeUtc` everywhere
  `MonoAndroidHelper.CopyIfChanged` is used
- The `_CopyIntermediateAssemblies` target appeared to have a typo. It
  was running a `<Touch />` on `ResolvedUserAssemblies` where it
  looked like it should be `ResolvedAssemblies` from the above
  `<Copy />`
- The `_AddStaticResources` target needed a `<Touch />` for
  `mono.android.jar`

This fix should improve our incremental build times dramatically, as
these timestamps caused other targets to run that slow things down.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unable to load DLL e_sqlite3" (#2744) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

When trying to run a Xamarin Forms WPF that includes a SQLite database it errors with

System.TypeInitializationException
  HResult=0x80131534
  Message=The type initializer for 'Microsoft.Data.Sqlite.SqliteConnection' threw an exception.
  Source=Microsoft.Data.Sqlite
  StackTrace:
   at Microsoft.Data.Sqlite.SqliteConnection..ctor(String connectionString)
   at TestUsingSQLite.MainPage..ctor() in C:\Temp\TestUsingSQLite\TestUsingSQLite\MainPage.xaml.cs:line 19
   at TestUsingSQLite.App..ctor() in C:\Temp\TestUsingSQLite\TestUsingSQLite\App.xaml.cs:line 14
   at TestUsingSQLite.WPF.MainWindow..ctor() in C:\Temp\TestUsingSQLite\TestUsingSQLite.WPF\MainWindow.xaml.cs:line 30

Inner Exception 1:
TargetInvocationException: Exception has been thrown by the target of an invocation.

Inner Exception 2:
DllNotFoundException: Unable to load DLL 'e_sqlite3': The specified module could not be found. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a Xamarin Cross Platform application
2. Add the WPF project per online instructions https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/xamarin/xamarin-forms/platform/wpf 
3. Add reference to Microsoft.Data.Sqlite

### Expected Behavior
Did not expect to get a sqlite3 error. Tried adding a number of different nuget packages that had SQLite components but none resolved the issue.

### Actual Behavior
Got an unable to load dll error

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: XamarinForms.Platform.WPF v3.1.0.469394-pre1
- Last known good version: NA
- IDE: Visual Studio Enterprise 15.7.1
- Platform Target Frameworks: WPF
- Nuget Packages: Microsoft.Data.Sqlite, NETStandard.Library, Xamarin.Forms, Xamarin.Forms.Platform.WPF.
[TestUsingSQLite.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/2009778/TestUsingSQLite.zip)

- Affected Devices:

### Screenshots

<!-- If the issue is a visual issue, please include screenshots showing the problem if possible -->

### Reproduction Link

<!-- Please upload or provide a link to a reproduction case -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[UWP] An InkCanvas in a Custom Renderer in a <Frame> does not work" (#2748) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description

I crated a custom control to host an `InkCanvas` in an app, but when placed inside a `<Frame>`, the ink does not work.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new Forms view
2. Create a new native control that hosts an `InkCanvas`
3. Create a custom renderer
4. Put the custom view into a `<Frame>`
5. Drawing does not work

### Expected Behavior

Drawing should work in a `<Frame>`.

### Actual Behavior

Drawing does not work.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 2.5.x and 3.0.x
- Last known good version: -
- IDE: VS2017
- Platform Target Frameworks: 
  - UWP:  10.0.16299.0 
- Affected Devices: Surface Book

### Reproduction Link

A full repro repo ;) lives here: https://github.com/mattleibow/FrameBlockers

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Suggestion] Opinionated cross-platform theme" (#2721) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
## Title
Create a theme or library, that when applied to an existing XF project, the app will be styled and rendered strictly **the same** on all platforms, using unified view sizes, docking, padding etc.

## Rationale

Xamarin.Forms has been great for consumer apps. For LoB apps it's a hard time.
LoB apps', especially in-company apps, have a very strong bias towards productivity and layout of apps vs. their design and graphics which are 2nd level priority.

You often need adaptive screens that can run both on mobile and laptops or tablets, and on any platform.

With this in mind, it doesn't always make sense to have the UI render differently per platform given the screen sizes are equal (thus requiring you to fine-tune it specifically to each platform).
The important feature would be adaptivity and responsiveness, not 'native look and feel'.

#### Difficulty
Intermediate

Related: #2415.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "MacOS VSTS Agent doesn't build successfully when triggered from Visual Studio Online" (#4096) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
One of our VSTS MacOS Agent fails to build through VSO although local build works just fine. I’ve searched online and it seems like the most common cause of this is an XCode/Xamarin update which requires you to manually install some components but I have no such issues on the Mac Agent. I have another Mac that works just fine when triggered from VSO, running on same OS, XCode & Xamarin version.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Setup Mac as a VSO Agent (follow instructions on Xamarin Docs)
2. Run a Xamarin project build locally (works)
3. Trigger a build from VSO of the same project (doesn't work)

### Expected Behavior
Successfully being able to build the project

### Actual Behavior
Xamarin project fails to build when triggered from VSO

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add support for Mac.Bindings projects on Windows" (#3912) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Library authors need to be able to build all the platforms in a single build (or a CI build). At the moment this is not possible because Mac is missing UWP support, and Windows is missing Mac.Bindings support. The shortest way to get there is to add support for Mac.Bindings on Windows.

At the moment it is unclear if this support will be full (like iOS) or build (like Mac). That will be decided based on effort. Full support will require a Windows computer connected to a Mac (like iOS does).

This is an enhancement and ongoing. More information will be added here when available, and also commits will be linked when they happen on the open source repo.

> VS bug [#597758](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/597758)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Indexing via property causing a crash when deserializing JSON to dynamic" (#4093) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Deserialize a JSON payload into a dynamic object e.g:
`var dynamicObject = JsonConvert.DeserializeObject<dynamic>(payload);`
2. Access a property of this dynamic via indexed property e.g: 
`var results = dynamicObject["results"];`
3. Run this code on an iOS emulator (bug appears on iOS emulator only, not iOS device/Android)

### Expected Behavior
The value portion of the JSON key/value pair is retrieved and stored in the results variable
### Actual Behavior
Crash, with 'Cannot apply indexing with [] to an expression of type 'Newtonsoft.Json.Linq.JObject''

present and makes the build fail.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[SceneKit] Makes SCNRenderingOptions.RenderingApi use the right key" (#4090) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/issues/4087

`SCNRenderingOptions.RenderingApi` is using the wrong key to
set its dictionary container value that should come from
`SCNRenderingOptionsKeys.RenderingApiKey`.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Crash when setting RenderingApi on SCNRenderingOptions" (#4087) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
The key for `RenderingApi` seems to be incorrect on iOS 11.3 and using it results in an ArgumentNull exception.

### Steps to Reproduce

```csharp
new SCNView (UIScreen.MainScreen.Bounds, new SCNRenderingOptions {
            RenderingApi = SCNRenderingApi.Metal,
        })
```

1. Run that code on iOS 11.3
2. Note the crash

### Expected Behavior

SCNView is created with Metal.

### Actual Behavior

Crash

```
System.ArgumentNullException: Value cannot be null.
Parameter name: key
  at Foundation.DictionaryContainer.NullCheckAndRemoveKey (Foundation.NSString key, System.Boolean removeEntry) [0x0001e] in /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/11.10.1.174/src/Xamarin.iOS/Foundation/DictionaryContainer.cs:330 
  at Foundation.DictionaryContainer.SetNumberValue (Foundation.NSString key, System.Nullable`1[T] value) [0x00000] in /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/11.10.1.174/src/Xamarin.iOS/Foundation/DictionaryContainer.cs:390 
  at SceneKit.SCNRenderingOptions.set_RenderingApi (System.Nullable`1[T] value) [0x00009] in /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/11.10.1.174/src/Xamarin.iOS/SceneKit/SCNRenderingOptions.cs:20 
```
